newsitem.title: UK: London Transport starts Tube extension plan probe.
newsitem.headline: London Transport starts Tube extension plan probe.

text.p: London Transport confirmed on Wednesday it was investigating the planned extension of the Underground's Jubilee Line, but declined to comment on reports that the project was running behind schedule.
The Evening Standard newspaper reported that the 2.6 billion pound project -- already over budget -- would be delayed by at least six months past its scheduled March 1998 opening.
Work on the 16-kilometre extension, a highly-complex project that involved burrowing under London's famous Big Ben tower, began in 1993 and originally expected to cost 1.7 billion pounds.
The underground artery would link the centre of the capital to office developments such as Canary Wharf in east London.
"We are holding further discussions within our team and with the Department of Transport," London Transport chairman Peter Ford said in a statement.
"We hope to be able to confirm very quickly the details of the likely opening date of the extension."

London's underground train system, known as the Tube, faces possible privatisation under the ruling Conservative Party, which has criticised its perceived decline in service and reduced its government funding.
But the opposition Labour Party, favourites to win the national election due by May 22, has said it is firmly committed to keeping the Tube in public hands.
A London Transport spokeswoman said the Jubilee Line investigation involved every area of the project, but she would not comment on the reports that the project would be delayed.
"We can't possibly speculate before we get the results of the investigation," she said, adding that the authority hoped to have something to report by next week.
The project was now in the process of fitting equipment like ticket machines in the stations following the completion of tunnelling work, she said.
The extension hit a six-month snag in 1994 when the transport authority stopped work to evaluate problems at an unrelated project that used similar tunnelling technology.
